bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A family unit is identified for the purposes of subsection (1) (a) if the family unit, while in receipt of income assistance, ceased to be eligible for income assistance

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a date the family unit included a person aged 65 or older,
as a result of a person in the family unit receiving an award of compensation under the Criminal Injury Compensation Act or an award of benefits under the Crime Victim Assistance Act, or
as a result of a person in the family unit receiving a payment under the settlement agreement approved by the Supreme Court in Action No. S50808, Kelowna Registry.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (5), a person's status as a main continued person under subsection (1) is suspended for a calendar month if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person fails to meet an applicable income test under subsection (7) in the calendar month and in each of the immediately preceding 12 calendar months, and
the person's continuation date is before those immediately preceding 12 calendar months.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (4) does not apply to a person who is a main continued person under subsection (1) as a result of having been part of a family unit identified in subsection (3) (c).

A person's status as a dependent continued person under subsection (2) of a main continued person under subsection (1) is suspended if the main continued person's status is suspended under subsection (4).
For the purposes of subsection (4), a main continued person under subsection (1) meets the income test for a calendar month if,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case that the main continued person is aged 65 or older or the main continued person's family unit includes a person aged 65 or older, the main continued person or another person in the family unit is in receipt of a qualifying federal benefit, and

in the case that neither the main continued person nor another person in the main continued person's family unit is aged 65 or older, the adjusted net income of the main continued person does not exceed the amount set out in section 11 (3) of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (7) (b),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjusted net income has the same meaning as in section 7.6 of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, and
a reference in section 7.6 of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation to an "eligible person" is to be read as a reference to the main continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite this Division, a person is not eligible, as a main continued person under subsection (1), to receive a health supplement under this Division for the calendar month in which the person's continuation date occurs.

Despite this Division, a person is not eligible, as a dependent continued person under subsection (2) of a main continued person under subsection (1), to receive a health supplement under this Division for the calendar month in which the main continued person's continuation date occurs.
Subject to subsection (4), a person is a main continued person if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person was, on or after September 1, 2015,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: part of a family unit identified in subsection (3) on the date the family unit ceased to be eligible for income assistance, and
a recipient of income assistance on the date referred to in subparagraph (i), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person has not, since the date referred to in paragraph (a) (i), been part of a family unit in receipt of income assistance, hardship assistance or disability assistance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is a dependent continued person if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person was a dependent child of a main continued person under subsection (1) on the main continued person's continuation date, and
the person is currently a dependent child of that main continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A family unit is identified for the purposes of subsection (1) (a) if the family unit, while in receipt of income assistance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ceased to be eligible for income assistance as a result of employment income, and
included on the date the family unit ceased to be eligible for income assistance

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a dependent child, or
a person providing care to a supported child.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (1) (b), a person ceases be a main continued person under subsection (1) one year after the first day of the calendar month immediately following the calendar month in which the person's continuation date occurred.

Despite this Division, a person is not eligible, as a main continued person under subsection (1), to receive a health supplement under this Division for the calendar month in which the person's continuation date occurs.

Despite this Division, a person is not eligible, as a dependent continued person under subsection (2) of a main continued person under subsection (1), to receive a health supplement under this Division for the calendar month in which the main continued person's continuation date occurs.
The minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 2 [general health supplements] or 3 [medical equipment and devices] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the family unit includes a qualifying person, or
the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is a continued person under section 66.3 (1) or (2) [access to medical services only], or

is a continued person under section 66.4 (1) [access to transitional health services] and was, on the person's continuation date, a qualifying person or part of a family unit that then included a qualifying person, or
is a continued person under section 66.4 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 145/2015, Sch. 1, s. 8 (b).]

Subject to subsection (3), the minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 2 [general health supplements] or 3 [medical equipment and devices] of Schedule C to or for a family unit if the health supplement is provided to or for a recipient in the family unit who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has received income assistance under the BC Benefits (Income Assistance) Act or the Act continuously from March 31, 1997 and on March 30, 1997 was eligible under section 37 (1) (a) of the BC Benefits (Income Assistance) Regulations, B.C. Reg. 272/96, as it read on March 30, 1997, for the health care services and benefits referred to in that provision, or
is a dependant of a recipient referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) applies only until the earlier of the following dates:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date the recipient ceases to receive income assistance;
the first day of the calendar month after the minister makes a determination that the recipient, or any dependant of the recipient other than a dependent child, is capable of accepting employment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 145/2015, Sch. 1, s. 8 (b).]

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 2.1 [optical supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the minister may provide a health supplement under section 2.2 [eye examination supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health supplement under subsection (1) may only be provided to or for a person once in any 24 calendar month period.
A health supplement under subsection (1) may only be provided if payment for the service is not available under the Medicare Protection Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 4 [dental supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the family unit includes a person with persistent multiple barriers to employment, or
the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is a continued person, and
meets any of the following criteria:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the person is under 19 years of age;

the person was, on the person's continuation date, a person with persistent multiple barriers to employment or part of a family unit that then included a person with persistent multiple barriers to employment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a crown and bridgework supplement under section 4.1 of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who has persistent multiple barriers to employment, or
a family unit, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is a continued person, and
was, on the person's continuation date, a person with persistent multiple barriers to employment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 5 [denture supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance or hardship assistance, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is not eligible for a health supplement under subsection (1) unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is not eligible for a supplement under section 68 [dental supplements], and
the person has had tooth extractions that were performed in the last 6 months because of pain and resulted in the person requiring a full upper denture, a full lower denture or both.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 6 [emergency dental supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide orthodontic supplements to or for a family unit in receipt of income assistance if the orthodontic supplements are provided to or for a person in the family unit who meets the conditions under subsection (2) and who is under 19 years of age.

For a person referred to in subsection (1) to be eligible for orthodontic supplements, the person's family unit must have no resources available to cover the cost of the orthodontic supplements and the person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have severe skeletal dysplasia with jaw misalignment by 2 or more standard deviations, and
obtain prior authorization from the minister for the orthodontic supplements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 313/2007, s. 1 (f).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dental and optical supplements — healthy kids program
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a health supplement in accordance with section 7 [dental and optical services — healthy kids program] of Schedule C to or for a family unit if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age and who is not eligible to receive the supplement under another provision of this Division or under Division 4 [Health Supplements] of Part 5 of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Hearing instrument supplement — healthy kids program
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a health supplement in accordance with section 7.1 [hearing instruments — healthy kids program] of Schedule C to or for a family unit if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age and who is not eligible to receive the supplement under another provision of this Division or under Division 4 [Health Supplements] of Part 5 of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the minister may pay for a diet supplement in accordance with section 8 [diet supplements] of Schedule C that is provided to or for a family unit in receipt of income assistance or hardship assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is described in section 8 (1) of Schedule C, and
is not described in section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is not eligible for a supplement under subsection (1) unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is not receiving another nutrition-related supplement, and
a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian confirms in writing the need for the special diet.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a nutritional supplement for up to 3 months to or for a family unit in receipt of income assistance or hardship assistance, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is not receiving another nutrition-related supplement, and

a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian confirms in writing that the person has an acute short-term need for caloric supplementation to a regular dietary intake to prevent critical weight loss while recovering from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: surgery,
a severe injury,
a serious disease, or
side effects of medical treatment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, tube feed nutritional supplement means a liquid nutritional product that is fed to a person via a tube to the stomach or intestines of the person and the pumps, tubes, bags and other medical equipment or supplies that are required to feed the liquid nutritional product to the person.
Subject to subsection (3), the minister may provide a tube feed nutritional supplement to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance or hardship assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is not described in section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A, or
a family unit, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is a continued person, and
was, on the person's continuation date, receiving the supplement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a tube feed nutritional supplement under this section if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian confirms in writing that the person's primary source of nutrition is through tube feeding,
the person is not receiving another nutrition-related supplement, and
there are no resources available to the person to pay for the tube feed nutritional supplement.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide the type of health supplement referred to in section 10 [infant formula] of Schedule C, in accordance with that section, to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a dependent child in the family unit,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a dependent child in the family unit, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a dependent child in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the minister may provide a natal supplement in accordance with section 9 [natal supplement] of Schedule C to or for a family unit in receipt of income assistance or hardship assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is not described in section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A.
A family unit is not eligible to receive a supplement under subsection (1) unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person in the family unit is pregnant, as confirmed in writing by a medical practitioner, a nurse practitioner or a midwife, or
the family unit includes a dependent child who is 12 months of age or younger.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Health supplement for persons facing direct and imminent life threatening health need

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide to a family unit any health supplement set out in sections 2 (1) (a) and (f) [general health supplements] and 3 [medical equipment and devices] of Schedule C, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is otherwise not eligible for the health supplement under this regulation, and if the minister is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person faces a direct and imminent life threatening need and there are no resources available to the person's family unit with which to meet that need,
the health supplement is necessary to meet that need,
the adjusted net income of any person in the family unit, other than a dependent child, does not exceed the amount set out in section 11 (3) of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, and
the requirements specified in the following provisions of Schedule C, as applicable, are met:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: paragraph (a) or (f) of section (2) (1);
sections 3 to 3.12, other than paragraph (a) of section 3 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1) (c),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjusted net income has the same meaning as in section 7.6 of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, and
a reference in section 7.6 of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation to an "eligible person" is to be read as a reference to a person in the family unit, other than a dependent child.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement for alcohol or drug treatment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement for the cost of treatment, counselling or related services for an alcohol or drug problem that is provided to a person in a family unit who is a recipient of income assistance or hardship assistance or a dependent child of a recipient of income assistance or hardship assistance, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that the recipient or dependent child needs the treatment, counselling or related services and there are no resources available to the family unit to cover the costs, and
the recipient or dependent child receives the minister's approval before incurring those costs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount of the supplement under this section is limited to a total of not more than $500 for all treatment, counselling and related services provided to any one person over the previous 12 consecutive calendar months.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 145/2015, Sch. 1, s. 14.]
The minister may provide a health supplement set out in section 11 of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of income assistance, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the family unit includes a qualifying person, or
the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a main continued person under section 66.3 (1),
a dependent continued person under section 66.3 (2),
a main continued person under section 66.4 (1) and was, on the person's continuation date, a qualifying person, or part of a family unit that included a qualifying person, on that date, or
a dependent continued person under section 66.4 (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Alternative hearing assistance supplement — healthy kids program
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a health supplement set out in section 11 of Schedule C if all of the following conditions apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the supplement is provided to or for a family unit that includes a person who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is eligible for supplemental services under section 10 (1) (c), (e) or (f) of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, or
has been determined to be eligible for supplemental services under section 11 of that regulation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age and who is not eligible to receive the supplement under

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: another provision of this Division, or
Division 4 [Health Supplements] of Part 5 of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: To be eligible to participate in a self-employment program established or funded by the minister under section 7 of the Act, a recipient must qualify under section 2 of this regulation as a person with persistent multiple barriers to employment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may require a recipient who is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: applying to participate in a self-employment program, or
participating in a self-employment program

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to provide, for the acceptance of the minister and within the time specified by the minister, a business plan for the small business the recipient is operating or proposes to operate under the self-employment program.

If a recipient provides a business plan under subsection (1) that is not acceptable to the minister, the minister may return the business plan to the recipient with directions and the recipient may resubmit the business plan within the time specified by the minister for that purpose.
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a recipient fails to provide a business plan in the time specified under subsection (1) or (2), as applicable, or
a recipient provides a business plan that is not acceptable to the minister,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the recipient is not or ceases to be eligible to participate in the self-employment program.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a recipient who is participating in a self-employment program is operating a small business under the program, the recipient must, in addition to the report required under section 33, provide a monthly report to the minister in the form and at the time specified by the minister, setting out, for the period covered by the report, as required by the form, the business activities, earnings, expenses, assets and liabilities of the small business the recipient is operating.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Consequences in Relation to Outstanding Arrest Warrants

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement to prevent undue hardship while dealing with outstanding arrest warrant

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit of an applicant or recipient for whom a warrant for arrest within the meaning of section 15.2 [consequences in relation to outstanding arrest warrants] of the Act has been issued for the purposes of section 15.2 (2) (a) of the Act, if the minister considers that undue hardship will otherwise occur.
A supplement under this section may be provided only for the calendar month in which the supplement is requested.
A supplement under this section may be provided for only three consecutive calendar months unless the minister authorizes up to three more consecutive monthly payments.
Despite any other section of this regulation, the maximum amount of a supplement provided under subsection (1) is the difference between

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the maximum amount of income assistance determined under Schedule A for the calendar month for a family unit that matches the family unit in size but does not include a person for whom a warrant for arrest within the meaning of section 15.2 of the Act has been issued, and
the amount of income assistance provided for the calendar month to the family unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A recipient of a supplement must agree in writing to repay the amount paid under this section.
In this section, living cost means the cost of accommodation and meals required for a person or family unit to return to the jurisdiction that issued the warrant.
The minister may provide a supplement to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an applicant or recipient for whom a warrant for arrest within the meaning of section 15.2 [consequences in relation to outstanding arrest warrants] of the Act has been issued for the purposes of section 15.2 (2) (b) (i) of the Act, or
the family unit of an applicant or recipient for whom a warrant for arrest within the meaning of section 15.2 of the Act has been issued for the purposes of section 15.2 (2) (b) (ii) of the Act,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are no resources available to the family unit to cover the cost of returning to the jurisdiction that issued the warrant, and
the minister is satisfied that the supplement will be used by the person or family unit to return to the jurisdiction that issued the warrant to deal with the warrant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any other section of this regulation, a supplement provided under subsection (2) is limited to an amount not to exceed the cost of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the least expensive appropriate mode of transportation, and
the least expensive appropriate living cost

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to return the person or family unit to the jurisdiction that issued the warrant.
A recipient of a supplement must agree in writing to repay the amount paid under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: detained person means a person described in section 15 [effect of being in prison or other lawful place of confinement];
person in special care means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receives accommodation and care in a special care facility or a private hospital, or
is admitted to a hospital because the person requires extended care;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: removed child, in relation to a family unit, means a dependent child who is living away from the ordinary residence of the family unit under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an interim order or temporary custody order under the Child, Family and Community Service Act, or
an agreement under section 6, 7 or 8 of that Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: specified person means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a removed child,
a detained person, or
a person in special care.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a housing stability supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for income assistance or hardship assistance on account of one or more of the following persons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a deceased person who was part of the family unit, if the family unit was eligible for income assistance, disability assistance or hardship assistance for the calendar month of the death and all subsequent calendar months;

a specified person who is part of the family unit, if the family unit included the specified person in, and was eligible for income assistance, disability assistance or hardship assistance for, the calendar month in which the person became a specified person and all subsequent calendar months.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be provided as a supplement under this section for a calendar month on account of persons described in subsection (1) (a) or (b) is the lesser of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the greater of zero and the difference between

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the actual shelter costs of the family unit for the month, and
the shelter allowance calculated under Schedule A or Schedule D, as applicable, for the family unit for the month, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the difference between

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount that would be determined under Schedule A, Schedule D, Schedule A of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Regulation or Schedule D of that regulation, as applicable, for the family unit for the month if the persons were not deceased persons or specified persons, and

the amount determined under Schedule A or Schedule D, as applicable, of this regulation, excluding an amount described in section 8 (2) (b) (i) [people in special care] of Schedule A, for the family unit for the month.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Housing stability supplement — family unit with only detained persons

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a housing stability supplement to or for a family unit that includes only one or more detained persons if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit included the persons in the calendar months in which the persons became detained persons and all subsequent calendar months, and

the family unit was, or would have been but for the detentions, eligible for income assistance, disability assistance or hardship assistance for the calendar months in which the persons became detained persons and all subsequent calendar months.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be provided as a supplement under this section for a calendar month on account of the detained persons is the lesser of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the actual shelter costs of the family unit for the month, and
the income assistance or hardship assistance, as applicable, for which the family unit would be eligible for the month if the persons were not detained persons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a supplement under this Division may be provided for only 3 consecutive calendar months unless the minister authorizes up to 3 more consecutive monthly payments.
The time limit in subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a supplement that is provided on account of a removed child.
The time limit in subsection (1) is restarted in relation to a supplement that is provided on account of a person if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person dies while a specified person, or
the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: was a detained person and becomes a person in care,
was a person in care and becomes a detained person,
was a person in care in a hospital or private hospital and becomes a person in care in a special care facility, or
was a person in care in a special care facility and becomes a person in care in a hospital or private hospital.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: appellant means a person who commences an appeal under section 21 of the Act;
party means, in relation to an appeal to the tribunal, the appellant and the minister whose decision is under appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How a request to reconsider a decision is made

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who wishes the minister to reconsider a decision referred to in section 17 (1) of the Act must deliver a request for reconsideration in the form specified by the minister to the ministry office where the person is applying for or receiving assistance.
A request under subsection (1) must be delivered within 20 business days after the date the person is notified of the decision referred to in section 17 (1) of the Act and may be delivered by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: leaving it with an employee in the ministry office, or
being received through the mail at that office.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister must reconsider a decision referred to in section 17 (1) of the Act, and mail a written determination on the reconsideration to the person who delivered the request under section 79 (1) [how a request to reconsider a decision is made],

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 10 business days after receiving the request, or
if the minister considers it necessary in the circumstances and the person consents, within 20 business days after receiving the request.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Decisions that may not be appealed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following categories of supplements are not appealable to the tribunal:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 313/2007, s. 1 (g).]
reconsideration and appeal supplements under section 56.6;
supplements related to employment plans under section 56;
access to a program established or funded under the Act;
confirmed job supplements under section 56.1;
supplements under section 77.4;
supplements under section 77.5.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision to refuse to provide income assistance, hardship assistance or a supplement is not appealable to the tribunal if the person who would bring the appeal is awaiting a reconsideration of the minister or the decision of a panel on an earlier request for reconsideration the person made, or an appeal the person brought, respecting the same matter.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 48/2010, Sch. 1, s. 1 (b).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prescribed qualifications for members, vice-chairs and the chair of the tribunal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To be eligible for appointment as a member to the tribunal, a person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have an understanding of the essential elements for the conduct of a fair and objective appeal,

have an understanding of the key aspects of the Act and its regulations, the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act and its regulations, and the Child Care Subsidy Act and its regulations,
not be an employee, or have been an employee within the past 6 months, in the ministry of a minister charged with the administration of the Act,
not be a recipient under the Act or the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act, and

not have a personal, professional, financial or other interest in matters coming before the tribunal that would cause a reasonably informed person to have a reasonable perception that the tribunal member would not be independent and impartial.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To be eligible for appointment as a chair or vice-chair of the tribunal, a person must, in addition to the requirements in subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have demonstrated skills regarding management, financial administration and human resource development, and
have demonstrated knowledge of administrative law.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A member of the tribunal, other than the chair or a vice-chair of the tribunal, shall receive for each appeal heard,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: $225 for acting as a panel chair, unless the chair of the tribunal determines that the appeal is extraordinarily complex and requires an extraordinary amount of time to prepare for, hear and provide written reasons, in which case the member acting as the panel chair shall receive $450, and
$145 for acting as a member of a panel other than as a panel chair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, 2 or more appeals that are consolidated under section 86 (e) and heard at one hearing count as one appeal.
Subsection (1) applies to a member of the tribunal for no more than 3 appeals the member hears on the same day.

bcl:section.bcl:text: To commence an appeal, an applicant or recipient must complete an appeal form specified by the minister and must submit that form to the chair of the tribunal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time period for scheduling and conducting hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A hearing must be held within 15 business days after the appeal form is delivered under section 84, unless the chair of the tribunal and the parties consent to a later date.
The chair of the tribunal must notify the parties of the date, time and place of a hearing described in subsection (1) at least 2 business days before the hearing is to commence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The practices and procedures of a panel include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party to an appeal may be represented by an agent;
the panel may hear an appeal in the absence of a party if the party was notified of the hearing;
the parties may call witnesses to give evidence before the panel;
a witness may not be present at the hearing before giving evidence unless the witness is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an expert witness in the proceedings,
a party to the appeal, or
an agent representing a party to the appeal;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chair of the tribunal may

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: consolidate 2 or more appeals involving the same parties, and
direct that 2 or more appeals involving different parties will be heard together if the appeals involve substantially similar facts

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the appeals involve substantially similar facts, and
each of the parties to each of the appeals agrees to the appeals being consolidated or heard together;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chair and the members of a panel must send to the chair of the tribunal all documents submitted to the panel respecting an appeal within 5 business days after that panel makes its determination under section 24 (1) of the Act respecting the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The written determination of a panel under section 24 of the Act must be in the form specified by the minister and must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify the decision under appeal,
summarize the issues and relevant facts considered in the appeal,
set out the reasons on which the panel based its determination, and
specify the outcome of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The panel must within 5 business days of the conclusion of the hearing provide to the chair of the tribunal its determination in accordance with subsection (1).

On the request of the chair of a panel, the chair of the tribunal may extend the time limit under subsection (2) for the panel by no more than 10 additional business days if the chair of the tribunal is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the panel is making all reasonable efforts to provide the chair of the tribunal with its determination in a timely manner, and
the best interest of the parties are served by the extension.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the panel's determination is not provided to the chair of the tribunal within the later of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the end of the 5th business day following the conclusion of the hearing, and
the date approved under subsection (3) by the chair of the tribunal,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the determination is invalid, the panel is disbanded without receiving any remuneration, and another panel must be appointed under section 22 of the Act.

If another panel is appointed under section 22 of the Act as a result of subsection (4), section 85 applies to this other panel as though an appeal form had been delivered on the date of the appointment of the panel.
The chair of the tribunal must within 5 business days of receipt of a determination of a panel mail a copy of the panel's determination to the parties.
The tribunal and a panel must keep confidential all documents and information submitted to it respecting the hearing of an appeal.
Determinations of a panel must not be disclosed by the chair and members of the panel to any person other than the chair of the tribunal.
Appeal proceedings before a panel are confidential and the hearing is not open to the public.
Despite subsections (1) to (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chair of the tribunal may publish determinations of panels if all names, addresses and other identifying information are removed from the decision before publication, and

documents, information, determinations of a panel and matters arising in the course of appeal proceedings before a panel may be disclosed for purposes of the investigation for, or prosecution of, an offence under the laws of Canada or British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section and sections 89.1 and 89.2:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act offence means an offence under the Act or the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act;

benefit month, in relation to a family unit, means a calendar month for which the family unit is eligible for an amount of assistance under the Act or the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act, and, for certainty, consecutive benefit months need not be consecutive calendar months;

criminal code offence means an offence under the Criminal Code in relation to obtaining money, under the Act or the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act, by fraud or false or misleading representation;
deposit debt means a supplement provided to or for a family unit on a repayable basis under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 58 (2) [supplement to pay a security deposit], 58.1 (2) [supplement to pay a utility security deposit] or 58.2 (2) [supplement to pay a pet damage deposit], or

section 56 (2) [supplement to pay a security deposit], 56.1 (2) [supplement to pay a utility security deposit] or 56.2 (2) [supplement to pay a pet damage deposit] of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Regulation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: offence overpayment means an overpayment that is or was provided to or for a family unit as a result of a criminal code offence or Act offence for which a recipient in the family unit has been or is convicted, whether the conviction occurred before or after the date this section came into force;
overpayment means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an overpayment described in section 27 (1) [overpayments] of the Act or section 18 (1) [overpayments] of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act,

an amount of assistance provided under the Act to or for a family unit on a repayable basis, other than a supplement under section 58 (2) [supplement to pay a security deposit], 58.1 (2) [supplement to pay a utility security deposit] or 58.2 (2) [supplement to pay a pet damage deposit] of this regulation,

an amount of assistance provided under the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act to or for a family unit on a repayable basis, other than a supplement under section 56 (2) [supplement to pay a security deposit], 56.1 (2) [supplement to pay a utility security deposit] or 56.2 (2) [supplement to pay a pet damage deposit] of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Regulation, or
a debt referred to in section 42 [indebtedness under former Act] of the Act or section 33 [indebtedness under former Act] of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to sections 89.1 and 89.2, for a family unit that includes one or more recipients who are liable for one or more overpayments, the amount that is to be deducted for the purposes of section 28 (1) (b) [liability for and recovery of debts under Act] of the Act is $10 each benefit month, regardless of the number of overpayments.

Subject to sections 89.1 and 89.2, for a family unit that includes one or more recipients who are liable for one or more deposit debts, the amount that is to be deducted for the purposes of section 28 (1) (b) of the Act is $20 each benefit month, regardless of the number of deposit debts.

Subject to sections 89.1 and 89.2, for a family unit that includes one or more recipients who are liable for one or more offence overpayments, the amount that is to be deducted for the purposes of section 28 (1) (b) of the Act for a benefit month is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: $100 for each recipient in the family unit whose conviction for a criminal code offence or Act offence resulted in an offence overpayment, or
if the balance of the amounts of offence overpayments in relation to a recipient in the family unit is less than $100, that balance in relation to that recipient.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A deduction under subsection (3) in relation to an offence overpayment provided to or for a family unit as a result of a criminal code offence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: begins for the first benefit month following the date the recipient is convicted of the criminal code offence, and
continues for each consecutive benefit month until the amount of the offence overpayment is recovered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A deduction under subsection (3) in relation to an offence overpayment provided to or for a family unit as a result of an Act offence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: begins for the first benefit month following the date the recipient is convicted of the Act offence, and
continues, unless the amount of the offence overpayment is earlier recovered,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: after a first conviction of the recipient for an Act offence, until the deduction has been made for 12 consecutive benefit months in relation to the first offence overpayment,
after a second conviction of that recipient for an Act offence, until the deduction has been made for 24 consecutive benefit months in relation to the second offence overpayment, and
after a third or subsequent conviction of that recipient for an Act offence, until the amount of the third or subsequent offence overpayments is recovered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsections (1) to (5), if the amount of assistance for which a family unit is eligible for a benefit month is less than the minimum amount to be deducted under this section, the minimum amount that is to be deducted for the purposes of section 28 (1) (b) of the Act for the benefit month is the amount of assistance for which the family unit is eligible for that benefit month.

Despite subsections (4) (a) and (5) (a), if the conviction referred to in those subsections occurred before the date this section came into force, a deduction under subsection (4) or (5) begins for the first benefit month following the date this section came into force.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemptions from deductions for debts owed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 270/2019, App. 1, s. 20 (a).]
Section 89 (2) does not apply to a family unit for a benefit month if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit receives income assistance under section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A for the benefit month, or
section 89 (2.1) or (3) applies to the family unit for that benefit month.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 89 (2.1) does not apply to a family unit for a benefit month if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit receives income assistance under section 8 (2) (b) of Schedule A for the benefit month, or
section 89 (3) applies to the family unit for that benefit month.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 89 (3) does not apply to a family unit for a benefit month if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit receives income assistance under section 8 (2) (b) of Schedule A for the benefit month,
the minister is satisfied that the family unit is homeless or at risk of becoming homeless,
the minister is satisfied that a deduction under that section would result in danger to the health of a person in the family unit, or

a recipient in the family unit is liable for an offence overpayment but the person convicted of the criminal code offence or Act offence that resulted in the offence overpayment is not a member of the family unit for the benefit month.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 89 (2), (2.1) and (3), a deduction under section 28 (1) (b) of the Act may not be made from a supplement under Division 8 [Housing Stability Supplement] of Part 5.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Recovery of more than one type of debt

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) applies if the minister is entitled to recover more than one of the following types of debt in respect of a family unit or a recipient in a family unit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: overpayments under section 89 (2);
deposit debts under section 89 (2.1);
offence overpayments section 89 (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may recover the debts referred to in subsection (1) from the family unit or recipient in the family unit, as applicable, by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: making a deduction respecting only one of the types of debt per benefit month, and
making the deduction in accordance with the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the minister is entitled to recover debt as set out in subsection (1) (a), (b) and (c), subsection (1) (a) and (c) or subsection (1) (b) and (c), by deducting the amount set out in section 89 (3) until the total debt the minister is entitled to recover under section 89 (3) is fully recovered;

if the minister is entitled to recover debt as set out in subsection (1) (a) and (b), by deducting the amount set out in section 89 (2.1) until the total debt the minister is entitled to recover under section 89 (2.1) is fully recovered.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prescribed enactments for purposes of sections 28 (1) (b) and 29 (2) of the Act
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following Acts are prescribed:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the purposes of section 28 (1) (b) of the Act, the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act;
for the purposes of section 29 (2) of the Act, the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: income assistance or hardship assistance to or for a recipient by cheque or electronic funds transfer or in vouchers, and
a supplement to or for a recipient by cheque or electronic funds transfer or in vouchers or in kind.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 8/2006, s. (a).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Replacement of lost or stolen assistance cheque
bcl:section.bcl:text: If satisfied that an unendorsed assistance cheque has been lost or stolen, the minister may issue a replacement as long as,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of theft, the matter has been reported to police, and
in the case of loss or theft, the recipient

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: makes a declaration of the facts, and
undertakes to promptly deliver the lost or stolen cheque to the minister if it is recovered.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transitional benefit to attend mental health activity centre
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may continue to provide a family unit with an amount that, immediately before this section comes into force, the family unit was receiving as a travel allowance under section 75 (1) of the Income Assistance Regulation, B.C. Reg. 75/97, to enable a person in the family unit to attend a mental health activity centre.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition in respect of the change to asset limits
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite the repeal and replacement of section 9 (1) and (2) (b) of the Income Assistance Regulation, B.C. Reg. 75/95 and section 7 (1) and (2) (b) of the Youth Works Regulation, B.C. Reg. 77/97 on April 1, 2002 by B.C. Reg. 58/2002, section 9 (1) and (2) (b) of the Income Assistance Regulation and section 7 (1) and (2) (b) of the Youth Works Regulation, as they read on March 31, 2002, apply to the family unit of a recipient until the date the person's eligibility is next audited under section 34 [requirement for eligibility audit].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition in respect of repealed provisions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, repealed provision means sections 26, 27, 28 (2) (a) or (g), section 47 and Schedule D and section 13 (2) of Schedule A of the Income Assistance Regulation, B.C. Reg. 75/97 in force on March 31, 2002 and section 22, 23 or 24 (2) (a) or (g) of the Youth Works Regulation, B.C. Reg. 77/97 in force on March 31, 2002.
The minister must not provide assistance authorized under a repealed provision except an amount awarded on an appeal in respect of a calendar month prior to April, 2002.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Maximum amount of income assistance before deduction of net income

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section and sections 3 and 6 to 10 of this Schedule, the amount of income assistance referred to in section 28 (a) [amount of income assistance] of this regulation is the sum of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the monthly support allowance under section 2 of this Schedule for a family unit matching the family unit of the applicant or recipient, plus
the shelter allowance calculated under sections 4 and 5 of this Schedule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1) but subject to subsection (3), income assistance may not be provided in respect of a dependent child if support for that child is provided under section 8 (2) or 93 (1) (g) (ii) of the Child, Family and Community Service Act.
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application is made by a parenting dependent child under section 5 (4) [application by parent who is dependent youth] of this regulation,
the family unit is found eligible for income assistance, and
support is provided for the parenting dependent child or that individual's dependent child, or for both, under section 8 (2) or 93 (1) (g) (ii) of the Child, Family and Community Service Act,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the restriction in subsection (2) does not apply, but the amount of income assistance that may otherwise be provided to the family unit is to be reduced by the amount of that support.
For the purposes of this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: deemed dependent children, in relation to a family unit, means the persons in the family unit who are deemed to be dependent children under subsection (5);
warrant has the meaning of a warrant in section 15.2 [consequences in relation to outstanding arrest warrants] of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the family unit includes one or more dependent children or deemed dependent children, the support allowance under subsection (1) for a calendar month is increased by an amount equal to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total BC child adjustment amount for all dependent children and all deemed dependent children in the family unit, minus
the sum of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the family bonus, if any, paid to the family unit for the preceding month,

the Canada child benefit, if any, paid to the family unit for the preceding month in respect of dependent children in the family unit, up to a maximum of the BC child adjustment amount in respect of those dependent children, and

the total amount of the supplements, if any, provided to or for the family unit under section 61 [supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled family bonus] or 61.1 [supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled Canada child benefit] of this regulation for the current calendar month.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the amount calculated under subsection (2) is less than zero, it is deemed to be zero for the purposes of this section.

In calculating the adjustment under subsection (2), an amount that, under the Income Tax Act (British Columbia) or the Income Tax Act (Canada), is deducted or set off from the family bonus or the Canada child benefit must be treated as if it were paid to a person in the family unit.
The support allowance under subsection (1) for a calendar month is not increased under subsection (2) if a person in the family unit refuses to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: apply for the family bonus or the Canada child benefit for the preceding calendar month, or
accept the family bonus or the Canada child benefit for the preceding calendar month

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in respect of a dependent child in the family unit who is, or may be, a qualified dependant within the meaning of the Income Tax Act (Canada).
If a family unit includes a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately before reaching 19 years of age was a dependent child in the family unit, and
reached that age while attending secondary school,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the person is deemed to be a dependent child, for the purposes of this section, until the earlier of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the end of the school year in which the person reaches the age of 19 years, and
the date the person stops attending secondary school.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, if the family unit includes a deemed dependent child, the BC child adjustment amount applies in respect of the deemed dependent child as if the deemed dependent child was a dependent child.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In the calendar month that includes the income assistance application date, the monthly support allowance is prorated based on the number of days remaining in that calendar month, beginning with the date of that submission.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How actual shelter costs are calculated

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of this section, utility costs for a family unit's place of residence include only the following costs:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fuel for heating;
fuel for cooking meals;
water;
hydro;
garbage disposal provided by a company on a regular weekly or biweekly basis;
rental of one basic residential single-line telephone.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When calculating the actual monthly shelter costs of a family unit, only the following items are included:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: rent for the family unit's place of residence;
mortgage payments on the family unit's place of residence, if owned by a person in the family unit;
a house insurance premium for the family unit's place of residence if owned by a person in the family unit;
property taxes for the family unit's place of residence if owned by a person in the family unit;
utility costs;
the actual cost of maintenance and repairs for the family unit's place of residence if owned by a person in the family unit and if these costs have received the minister's prior approval.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If utility costs fluctuate, they may be averaged over the periods

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: beginning on October 1 and ending on March 31, and
beginning on April 1 and ending on September 30.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If 2 or more family units share the same place of residence, the actual shelter costs of any one of them are the smaller of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount calculated by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: dividing the actual shelter costs for all the family units by the number of persons occupying that place of residence, and
multiplying the result by the number of persons in that one family unit, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount declared by the family unit as the shelter costs for that family unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a family unit receiving room and board other than in a facility mentioned in section 8 (2) (b) (i) [people in special care] of this Schedule, the amount referred to in section 28 (a) [amount of income assistance] of this regulation is the smaller of the following amounts:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the sum of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the actual cost of the room and board, plus
$60 for each calendar month for each applicant or recipient, plus
$40 for each calendar month for each dependent child in the family unit;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount calculated under sections 1 to 5 of this Schedule for a family unit matching the applicant's or recipient's family unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 122/2019, App. 1, s. 11 (b).]

For the purposes of subsection (1) (a) (i), if the actual cost of room and board is less than the minimum determined under section 4 (2) (a) or (2.1) (a) for the family unit, the actual cost is conclusively deemed to be that minimum.

For a family unit that includes a person who has reached 65 years of age and receives federal old age security payments and includes a dependant, the amount referred to in section 28 (a) [amount of income assistance] of this regulation is the sum of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the support allowance calculated under section 2 and 3 of this Schedule for a family unit matching the applicant's or recipient's family unit, plus
the maximum shelter allowance calculated under section 4 of this Schedule for a family unit matching the applicant's or recipient's family unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) applies regardless of the family unit's actual shelter costs or whether the family unit is sharing residential accommodation or receiving room and board.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: People in special care or otherwise living away

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, person in special care and specified person have the same meanings as in section 77.6 [definitions — housing stability supplement] of this regulation.
For a family unit that includes one or more specified persons, the amount referred to in section 28 (a) [amount of income assistance] of this regulation is the sum of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount that would be calculated under this Schedule if the specified persons were not part of the family unit, and
for each specified person who is a person in special care,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the actual cost, if any, to the person of the accommodation and care at the rate approved by the minister for the type of the facility, and
a comforts allowance of $115.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty, this section applies in relation to a family unit that includes only one or more persons in special care and, in that case, the amount referred to in subsection (2) (a) is to be considered to be zero.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the amount of earned income calculated under subsection (6) is exempt for a family unit.

gross wages paid to employees of the small business, but not including wages paid to

equipment purchases or rentals;
contributions made under the Canada Pension Plan in respect of the person's self-employment earnings.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Earned income of a recipient of income assistance is exempted from the total income of the recipient's family unit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the recipient is participating in a self-employment program, and
the earned income is derived from operating a small business under the self-employment program in which the recipient is participating and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is used for permitted operating expenses of the small business, or
is deposited in a separate account, established by the recipient in a savings institution, which account

bcl:clause.bcl:text: consists exclusively of funds reserved by the recipient for the purpose of paying permitted operating expenses of that small business, and
the amount deposited does not increase the current balance of the separate account to a sum that exceeds $5 000, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is used for costs of renovations to the recipient's place of residence up to but not exceeding $5 000 in total or a greater amount accepted by the minister, if the renovations are part of a business plan accepted by the minister under section 77.2 of this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Withdrawals and expenditures from reserve account
bcl:section.bcl:text: The amount of any expenditure or withdrawal out of a separate account described in section 4 (2) (b) (ii) of this Schedule is earned income for all purposes of this regulation, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the expenditure or withdrawal is for the payment of permitted operating expenses of the small business referred to in section 4 (2) of this Schedule, and

in the case of a withdrawal, the amount withdrawn is used within one month after the date of withdrawal to pay permitted operating expenses of the small business referred to in section 4 (2) (b) (i) of this Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The only deductions permitted from unearned income are the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any income tax deducted at source from employment insurance benefits;
essential operating costs of renting self-contained suites.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

a criminal injury compensation award or other award, except the amount that would cause the family unit's assets to exceed, at the time the award is received, the limit applicable under section 11 [asset limits] of this regulation;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: disability-related costs,
the acquisition of a family unit's place of residence,
a registered education savings plan, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (2), a structured settlement annuity payment made to a person referred to in section 13 (2) (a) of this regulation if the payment is applied exclusively to or used exclusively for an item referred to in subparagraph (i), (ii), (iii) or (iv) of paragraph (d) of this subsection;

any of the following if applied exclusively to or used exclusively for disability-related costs to promote independence:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a payment made from a trust to or on behalf of a person referred to in section 13 (2) of this regulation;
a structured settlement annuity payment that, subject to subsection (2), is made to a person referred to in section 13 (2) (a) of this regulation;
money expended by a person referred to in section 13.1 (2) of this regulation from an intended registered disability savings plan or trust;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the portion of Canada Pension Plan Benefits that is calculated by the formula (A−B) x C, where

a benefit paid under section 22, 23 or 23.2 of the Employment Insurance Act (Canada) to any person in the family unit.
