bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Minister's discretion to exempt education related unearned income

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: day care costs means the difference between a student's actual day care costs and the maximum amount of child care subsidy that is available under the Child Care Subsidy Act to a family unit matching the student's family unit;

education costs, in relation to a student and a program of studies, means the costs, including the costs of tuition, student fees, books, equipment, supplies and transportation, that, in the opinion of the minister, are reasonably required for the student to participate in the program of studies.

education related living costs, in relation to a student and a program of studies, means the costs, other than education costs, including the costs of food, shelter, clothing, utilities and other living expenses, that, in the opinion of the minister, are reasonably required for the student to participate in the program of studies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may authorize an exemption for a student described in subsection (3) up to the sum of the student's education costs and day care costs, for a period of study, from the total amount of the following received by the student for the period of study:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a training allowance;
student financial assistance;
student grants, bursaries and scholarships;
disbursements from a registered education savings plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An exemption under subsection (2) may be authorized in respect of a student who is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a dependent child enrolled as a student in either a funded or an unfunded program of studies,
an applicant or a recipient enrolled

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as a part-time student in an unfunded program of studies, or
with the prior approval of the minister, as a full-time student in an unfunded program of studies, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person in a category listed in section 29 (4) [consequences of failing to meet employment-related obligations] of this regulation enrolled as a part-time student in a funded program of studies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may authorize an exemption for a student who is a recipient enrolled as a part-time student in a funded program of studies up to the sum of the student's education costs and day care costs, for a period of study, from the total amount of the following received by the student for the period of study:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a training allowance;
student grants, bursaries and scholarships, except student grants, bursaries and scholarships provided under the Canada Student Financial Assistance Act;
disbursements from a registered education savings plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may authorize an exemption for a student who is described in section 16 (1.1) [effect of family unit including full-time student] of this regulation up to the sum of the student's education costs, education related living costs and day care costs, for a period of study, from the total amount of the following received by the student for the period of study:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a training allowance;
student grants, bursaries and scholarships, except student grants, bursaries and scholarships provided under the Canada Student Financial Assistance Act;
disbursements from a registered education savings plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The deductions and exemptions in this Schedule apply only in the calendar month in which the income is actually received, despite any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date the income is payable;
the period for which the income is payable;
the date the income is reported to the minister;
the date the minister receives notice of the income.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), income that is received before the date that subsection (1) comes into force is subject to the application of section 9 of this regulation as it read immediately before subsection (1) came into force.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Backdated family bonus or Canada child benefit treated as unearned income

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: backdated Canada child benefit payment, in relation to a child benefits cheque, means the portion of the cheque, if any, attributable to the Canada child benefit for one or more calendar months preceding the calendar month in which the cheque is issued;

backdated family bonus payment, in relation to a child benefits cheque, means the portion of the cheque, if any, attributable to the family bonus for one or more calendar months preceding the calendar month in which the cheque is issued;

supplement means a supplement referred to in section 61 [supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled family bonus] or 61.1 [supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled Canada child benefit] of this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person in the applicant's or recipient's family unit receives a backdated family bonus payment or a backdated Canada child benefit payment and all or part of the payment is attributable to one or more calendar months for which the family unit was also provided with a supplement, the lesser of the following amounts must be treated as unearned income:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the portion of the backdated family bonus payment or the backdated Canada child benefit payment, as applicable, that is attributable to those calendar months for which the family unit was provided with a supplement;

the sum of the supplements that are attributable to those calendar months for which the family unit received the backdated family bonus payment or the backdated Canada child benefit payment, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1), an amount that, under the Income Tax Act (British Columbia) or the Income Tax Act (Canada), is deducted or set off from a family bonus or a Canada child benefit is considered to have been paid to a person in the applicant's or recipient's family unit.
Subsection (1) does not apply to an amount included in that portion of a child benefits cheque attributable to family bonus or Canada child benefit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to replace a lost or stolen cheque for which an amount was advanced under section 60 [advance for lost or stolen family bonus cheque] or 60.1 [advance for lost or stolen child benefits cheque — Canada child benefit] of this regulation, or

to replace a cheque for which no amount was advanced under section 60 [advance for lost or stolen family bonus cheque] or 60.1 [advance for lost or stolen child benefits cheque — Canada child benefit] of this regulation if the replacement is received in the calendar month following the calendar month for which the lost or stolen cheque was issued.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 48/2010, Sch. 1, s. 1 (q).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Backdated CPP treated as unearned income

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, pension benefit means a pension or other payment under the Canada Pension Plan (Canada).
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: income assistance is provided to a family unit for a calendar month or any portion of a calendar month that would not have been provided if a pension benefit had been paid for that calendar month, and

subsequently a pension benefit becomes payable or payment of a pension benefit may be made under the Canada Pension Plan (Canada) to a recipient in the family unit for that calendar month or any portion of that calendar month,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the amount of the pension benefit that becomes payable for that month or portion of that month must be treated as unearned income and is considered to have been received by the recipient in that month.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Schedule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: audiologist means an audiologist registered with the College of Speech and Hearing Health Professionals of British Columbia established under the Health Professions Act;
basic dental service means a dental service that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if provided by a dentist,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is set out in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Dentist that is effective September 1, 2017 and is published on the website of the ministry of the minister, and
is provided at the rate set out in that Schedule for the service and the category of person receiving the service,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if provided by a denturist,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is set out in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Denturist that is effective September 1, 2017 and is published on the website of the ministry of the minister, and
is provided at the rate set out in that Schedule for the service and the category of person receiving the service, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if provided by a dental hygienist,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is set out in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Dental Hygienist that is effective September 1, 2017 and is published on the website of the ministry of the minister, and
is provided at the rate set out in that Schedule for the service and the category of person receiving the service;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: basic eyewear and repairs means any of the following items that are provided by an optometrist, ophthalmologist or optician:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a child who has a new prescription, one pair of eye glasses per year consisting of the least expensive appropriate

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: single-vision or bifocal lenses, and
frames;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for any other person who has a new prescription, one pair of eye glasses every 3 years consisting of the least expensive appropriate

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: single-vision or bifocal lenses, and
frames;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a child or other person,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: new lenses at any time if an optometrist, ophthalmologist or optician confirms a change in refractive status in either eye,
a case for new eye glasses or lenses, and
necessary repairs to lenses or frames that come within this definition;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: change in refractive status means a change of not less than 0.5 dioptres to the spherical or cylinder lens, or a change in axis that equals or exceeds

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 20 degrees for a cylinder lens of 0.5 dioptres or less,
10 degrees for a cylinder lens of more than 0.5 dioptres but not more than 1.0 dioptre, and
3 degrees for a cylinder lens of more than 1.0 dioptre;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: dental hygienist means a dental hygienist registered with the British Columbia College of Oral Health Professionals;
dentist means a dentist registered with the British Columbia College of Oral Health Professionals;
denture services means services and items that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if provided by a dentist

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are set out under fee numbers 51101 to 51302 in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Dentist that is effective September 1, 2017 and is published on the website of the ministry of the minister, and
are provided at the rate set out in that Schedule for the service or item and the category of person receiving the service or item, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if provided by a denturist

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are set out under fee numbers 31310 to 31321 in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Denturist that is effective September 1, 2017 and is published on the website of the ministry of the minister, and
are provided at the rate set out in that Schedule for the service or item and the category of person receiving the service or item;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: denturist means a denturist registered with the British Columbia College of Oral Health Professionals;
emergency dental service means a dental service necessary for the immediate relief of pain that,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if provided by a dentist,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is set out in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Emergency Dental — Dentist, that is effective September 1, 2017 and is published on the website of the ministry of the minister, and
is provided at the rate set out in that Schedule for the service and the category of the person receiving the service, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if provided by a denturist,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is set out in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Emergency Dental — Denturist, that is effective September 1, 2017 and is published on the website of the ministry of the minister, and
is provided at the rate set out in that Schedule for the service and the category of the person receiving the service;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: eye examination means a full diagnostic examination of a person's eyes by an optometrist or an ophthalmologist, that includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a determination of the refractive status of the eyes and of the presence of any observed abnormality in the person's visual system,
any necessary tests connected to making determinations under paragraph (a), and
the provision of a written prescription for lenses if necessary;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: hearing instrument has the same meaning as in the Speech and Hearing Health Professionals Regulation, B.C. Reg. 413/2008;

hearing instrument practitioner means a hearing instrument practitioner registered with the College of Speech and Hearing Health Professionals of British Columbia established under the Health Professions Act;
occupational therapist means an occupational therapist registered with the College of Occupational Therapists of British Columbia established under the Health Professions Act;
ophthalmologist means a medical practitioner who practises ophthalmology;
optician means an optician registered with the College of Opticians of British Columbia established under the Health Professions Act;
optometrist means an optometrist registered with the College of Optometrists of British Columbia established under the Health Professions Act;
orthotist means a person who is certified by and in good standing with the Canadian Board for Certification of Prosthetists and Orthotists;
pedorthist means a person who is certified by and in good standing with the College of Pedorthics of Canada;
physical therapist means a physical therapist registered with the College of Physical Therapists of British Columbia established under the Health Professions Act;
physical therapy has the same meaning as in the Physical Therapists Regulation, B.C. Reg. 288/2008;

pre-authorized eyewear and repairs means eyewear and repairs provided by an optometrist, ophthalmologist or optician and for which pre-authorization is given by the minister, but does not include basic eyewear and repairs;

specialist means a medical practitioner recognized as a specialist in a field of medicine or surgery in accordance with the bylaws made by the board for the College of Physicians and Surgeons of British Columbia under section 19 (1) (k.3) and (k.4) of the Health Professions Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are the health supplements that may be paid for by the minister if provided to a family unit that is eligible under section 67 [general health supplements] of this regulation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: medical or surgical supplies that are, at the minister's discretion, either disposable or reusable, if the minister is satisfied that all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the supplies are required for one of the following purposes:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: wound care;
ongoing bowel care required due to loss of muscle function;
catheterization;
incontinence;
skin parasite care;
limb circulation care;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the supplies are

bcl:clause.bcl:text: prescribed by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner,
the least expensive supplies appropriate for the purpose, and
necessary to avoid an imminent and substantial danger to health;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: there are no resources available to the family unit to pay the cost of or obtain the supplies;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the following medical or surgical supplies that are, at the minister's discretion, either disposable or reusable, if the minister is satisfied that all the requirements described in paragraph (a) (ii) and (iii) are met in relation to the supplies:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: lancets;
needles and syringes;
ventilator supplies required for the essential operation or sterilization of a ventilator;
tracheostomy supplies;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consumable medical supplies, if the minister is satisfied that all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the supplies are required to thicken food;
all the requirements described in paragraph (a) (ii) and (iii) are met in relation to the supplies;

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1) (a), medical and surgical supplies do not include nutritional supplements, food, vitamins, minerals or prescription medications.

No more than 12 visits per calendar year are payable by the minister under this section for any combination of physical therapy services, chiropractic services, massage therapy services, non-surgical podiatry services, naturopathy services and acupuncture services.

If eligible under subsection (1) (c) and subject to subsection (2), the amount of a general health supplement under section 67 of this regulation for physical therapy services, chiropractic services, massage therapy services, non-surgical podiatry services, naturopathy services and acupuncture services is $23 for each visit.

If the minister provided a benefit to or for a person under section 2 (3) of Schedule C of the Income Assistance Regulation, B.C. Reg. 75/97, the Youth Works Regulation, B.C. Reg. 77/97 or the Disability Benefits Program Regulation, B.C. Reg. 79/97, as applicable, for the month during which the regulation was repealed, the minister may continue to provide that benefit to or for that person as a supplement on the same terms and conditions as previously until the earlier of the following dates:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date the conditions on which the minister paid the benefit are no longer met;
the date the person ceases to receive income assistance.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are the health supplements that may be paid for by the minister if provided to a family unit that is eligible under section 67.1 [optical supplements] of this regulation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: basic eyewear and repairs;
pre-authorized eyewear and repairs.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may pay a health supplement under section 67.2 [eye examination supplements] of this regulation for an eye examination that,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if provided by an optometrist, is provided for a fee that does not exceed $44.83, or
if provided by an ophthalmologist, is provided for a fee that does not exceed $48.90.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) to (5) of this section, the medical equipment and devices described in sections 3.1 to 3.12 of this Schedule are the health supplements that may be provided by the minister if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the supplements are provided to a family unit that is eligible under section 67 [general health supplements] of this regulation, and
all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the family unit has received the pre-authorization of the minister for the medical equipment or device requested;
there are no resources available to the family unit to pay the cost of or obtain the medical equipment or device;
the medical equipment or device is the least expensive appropriate medical equipment or device.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For medical equipment or devices referred to in sections 3.1 to 3.8 or section 3.12, in addition to the requirements in those sections and subsection (1) of this section, the family unit must provide to the minister one or both of the following, as requested by the minister:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a prescription of a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner for the medical equipment or device;
an assessment by an occupational therapist or physical therapist confirming the medical need for the medical equipment or device.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For medical equipment or devices referred to in section 3.9 (1) (b) to (g), in addition to the requirements in that section and subsection (1) of this section, the family unit must provide to the minister one or both of the following, as requested by the minister:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a prescription of a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner for the medical equipment or device;
an assessment by a respiratory therapist, occupational therapist or physical therapist confirming the medical need for the medical equipment or device.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (6), the minister may provide as a health supplement a replacement of medical equipment or a medical device, previously provided by the minister under this section or section 7.1 of this Schedule, that is damaged, worn out or not functioning if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is more economical to replace than to repair the medical equipment or device previously provided by the minister, and
the period of time, if any, set out in sections 3.1 to 3.12 of this Schedule, as applicable, for the purposes of this paragraph, has passed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (6), the minister may provide as a health supplement repairs of medical equipment or a medical device that was previously provided by the minister if it is more economical to repair the medical equipment or device than to replace it.
Subject to subsection (6), the minister may provide as a health supplement repairs of medical equipment or a medical device that was not previously provided by the minister if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the time of the repairs the requirements in this section and sections 3.1 to 3.12 of this Schedule, as applicable, are met in respect of the medical equipment or device being repaired, and
it is more economical to repair the medical equipment or device than to replace it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may not provide a replacement of medical equipment or a medical device under subsection (3) or repairs of medical equipment or a medical device under subsection (4) or (5) if the minister considers that the medical equipment or device was damaged through misuse.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — canes, crutches and walkers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2) of this section, the following items are health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to achieve or maintain basic mobility:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a cane;
a crutch;
a walker;
an accessory to a cane, a crutch or a walker.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A walking pole is not a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule.
In this section, wheelchair does not include a stroller.

Subject to subsection (4) of this section, the following items are health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to achieve or maintain basic mobility:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a wheelchair;
an upgraded component of a wheelchair;
an accessory attached to a wheelchair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of an item described in subsection (2) of this section is 5 years after the minister provided the item being replaced.
A high-performance wheelchair for recreational or sports use is not a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — wheelchair seating systems

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following items are health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to achieve or maintain a person's positioning in a wheelchair:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a wheelchair seating system;
an accessory to a wheelchair seating system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of an item described in subsection (1) of this section is 2 years from the date on which the minister provided the item being replaced.
In this section, scooter does not include a scooter with 2 wheels.

Subject to subsection (5) of this section, the following items are health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if all of the requirements set out in subsection (3) of this section are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a scooter;
an upgraded component of a scooter;
an accessory attached to a scooter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are the requirements in relation to an item referred to in subsection (2) of this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an assessment by an occupational therapist or a physical therapist has confirmed that it is unlikely that the person for whom the scooter has been prescribed will have a medical need for a wheelchair during the 5 years following the assessment;
the total cost of the scooter and any accessories attached to the scooter does not exceed $3 500 or, if subsection (3.1) applies, $4 500;
the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to achieve or maintain basic mobility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The maximum amount of $4 500 under subsection (3) (b) applies if an assessment by an occupational therapist or a physical therapist has confirmed that the person for whom the scooter has been prescribed has a body weight that exceeds the weight capacity of a conventional scooter but can be accommodated by a bariatric scooter.

The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of an item described in subsection (2) of this section is 5 years after the minister provided the item being replaced.
A scooter intended primarily for recreational or sports use is not a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — toileting, transfers and positioning aids

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: positioning chair does not include a lift chair;
transfer aid means a transfer board, transfer belt or slider sheet.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following items are health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to facilitate toileting or transfers of a person or to achieve or maintain a person's positioning:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a grab bar in a bathroom;
a bath or shower seat;
a bath transfer bench with hand held shower;
a tub slide;
a bath lift;
a bed pan or urinal;
a raised toilet seat;
a toilet safety frame;
a floor-to-ceiling pole in a bathroom or bedroom;
a portable commode chair;
a standing frame for a person for whom a wheelchair is medically essential to achieve or maintain basic mobility;
a positioning chair for a person for whom a wheelchair is medically essential to achieve or maintain basic mobility;
a transfer aid for a person for whom the transfer aid is medically essential to transfer from one position to another.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of an item described in subsection (1) of this section is 5 years from the date on which the minister provided the item being replaced.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — hospital bed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3) of this section, the following items are health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to facilitate transfers of a person to and from bed or to adjust or maintain a person's positioning in bed:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a hospital bed;
an upgraded component of a hospital bed;
an accessory attached to a hospital bed;
a positioning item on a hospital bed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of an item described in subsection (1) of this section is 5 years from the date on which the minister provided the item being replaced.
The following items are not health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an automatic turning bed;
a containment type bed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — pressure relief mattresses

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A pressure relief mattress is a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if the minister is satisfied that the pressure relief mattress is medically essential to prevent skin breakdown and maintain skin integrity.

The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of an item described in subsection (1) of this section is 5 years from the date on which the minister provided the item being replaced.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — floor or ceiling lift devices

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, floor or ceiling lift device means a device that stands on the floor or is attached to the ceiling and that uses a sling system to transfer a person.
A floor or ceiling lift device is a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister is satisfied that the floor or ceiling lift device is medically essential to facilitate transfers of a person in a bedroom or a bathroom;

the cost of the floor or ceiling lift device does not exceed $4 200 or, if the cost of the floor or ceiling lift device does exceed $4 200, the minister is satisfied that the excess cost is a result of unusual installation expenses.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of an item described in subsection (2) of this section is 5 years from the date on which the minister provided the item being replaced.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — breathing devices

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4) of this section, the following items are health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if all of the requirements set out in subsection (2) of this section are met,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a positive airway pressure device,
an accessory that is required to operate a positive airway pressure device, or
a supply that is required to operate a positive airway pressure device;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to monitor breathing,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an apnea monitor,
an accessory that is required to operate an apnea monitor, or
a supply that is required to operate an apnea monitor;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential for clearing respiratory airways,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a suction unit,
an accessory that is required to operate a suction unit, or
a supply that is required to operate a suction unit;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential for clearing respiratory airways,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a percussor,
an accessory that is required to operate a percussor, or
a supply that is required to operate a percussor;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to avoid an imminent and substantial danger to health,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a nebulizer,
an accessory that is required to operate a nebulizer, or
a supply that is required to operate a nebulizer;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to moisturize air in order to allow a tracheostomy patient to breathe,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a medical humidifier,
an accessory that is required to operate a medical humidifier, or
a supply that is required to operate a medical humidifier;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential to deliver medication,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an inhaler accessory device,
an accessory that is required to operate an inhaler accessory device, or
a supply that is required to operate an inhaler accessory device.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are the requirements in relation to an item referred to in subsection (1) (a) of this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the item is prescribed by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner;
a respiratory therapist has performed an assessment that confirms the medical need for the item;
the minister is satisfied that the item is medically essential for the treatment of moderate to severe sleep apnea.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of an item described in subsection (1) of this section is as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an item referred to in subsection (1) (a) (i), 5 years from the date on which the minister provided the item being replaced;
in the case of an item referred to in subsection (1) (a) (ii) or (iii), one year from the date on which the minister provided the item being replaced;
in the case of an apnea monitor, suction unit, percussor, nebulizer or medical humidifier, 5 years from the date on which the minister provided the item being replaced;
in the case of an inhaler accessory device, one year from the date on which the minister provided the device being replaced;
in the case of an accessory or supply for an item referred to in paragraph (c) or (d), one year from the date on which the minister provided the device being replaced.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A ventilator is not a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule.
In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: off-the-shelf, in relation to an orthosis, means a prefabricated, mass-produced orthosis that is not unique to a particular person;
orthosis means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a custom-made or off-the-shelf foot orthotic;
custom-made footwear;
a permanent modification to footwear;
off-the-shelf footwear required for the purpose set out in subsection (4.1) (a);
off-the-shelf orthopaedic footwear;
an ankle brace;
an ankle-foot orthosis;
a knee-ankle-foot orthosis;
a knee brace;
a hip brace;
an upper extremity brace;
a cranial helmet used for the purposes set out in subsection (7);
a torso or spine brace;
a foot abduction orthosis;
a toe orthosis;
a walking boot.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (3) to (11) of this section, an orthosis is a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the orthosis is prescribed by a medical practitioner or a nurse practitioner,
the minister is satisfied that the orthosis is medically essential to achieve or maintain basic functionality,
the minister is satisfied that the orthosis is required for one or more of the following purposes:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to prevent surgery;
for post-surgical care;
to assist in physical healing from surgery, injury or disease;
to improve physical functioning that has been impaired by a neuro-musculo-skeletal condition, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the orthosis is off-the-shelf unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner confirms that a custom-made orthosis is medically required, and
the custom-made orthosis is fitted by an orthotist, pedorthist, occupational therapist, physical therapist or podiatrist.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For an orthosis that is a custom-made foot orthotic, in addition to the requirements in subsection (2) of this section, all of the following requirements must be met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner confirms that a custom-made foot orthotic is medically required;
the custom-made foot orthotic is fitted by an orthotist, pedorthist, occupational therapist, physical therapist or podiatrist;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 144/2011, Sch. 1.]
the custom-made foot orthotic must be made from a hand-cast mold;
the cost of one pair of custom-made foot orthotics, including the assessment fee, must not exceed $450.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For an orthosis that is custom-made footwear, in addition to the requirements in subsection (2) of this section, the cost of the custom-made footwear, including the assessment fee, must not exceed $1 650.
For an orthosis that is off-the-shelf footwear, in addition to the requirements in subsection (2) of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the footwear is required to accommodate a custom-made orthosis, and
the cost of the footwear must not exceed $125.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For an orthosis that is off-the-shelf orthopaedic footwear, in addition to the requirements in subsection (2) of this section, the cost of the footwear must not exceed $250.

For an orthosis that is a knee brace, in addition to the requirements in subsection (2) of this section, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who prescribed the knee brace must have recommended that the knee brace be worn at least 6 hours per day.

For an orthosis that is an upper extremity brace, in addition to the requirements in subsection (2) of this section, the upper extremity brace must be intended to provide hand, finger, wrist, elbow or shoulder support.

For an orthosis that is a cranial helmet, in addition to the requirements in subsection (2) of this section, the cranial helmet must be a helmet prescribed by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner and recommended for daily use in cases of self abusive behaviour, seizure disorder, or to protect or facilitate healing of chronic wounds or cranial defects.

For an orthosis that is a torso or spine brace, in addition to the requirements in subsection (2) of this section, the brace must be intended to provide pelvic, lumbar, lumbar-sacral, thoracic-lumbar-sacral, cervical-thoracic-lumbar-sacral, or cervical spine support.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following items are not health supplements for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a prosthetic and related supplies;
a plaster or fiberglass cast;
a hernia support;
an abdominal support.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An accessory or supply that is medically essential to use an orthosis that is a health supplement under subsection (2) is a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — hearing instruments

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A hearing instrument is a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the hearing instrument is prescribed by an audiologist or hearing instrument practitioner, and
an audiologist or hearing instrument practitioner has performed an assessment that confirms the need for a hearing instrument.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a hearing instrument to or for a family unit under this section only if the person is not receiving a hearing assistance supplement under section 77.02 or 77.03 of this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical equipment and devices — non-conventional glucose meters

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, non-conventional glucose meter includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a continuous glucose monitoring meter, and
a talking glucose meter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A non-conventional glucose meter is a health supplement for the purposes of section 3 of this Schedule if the minister is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the glucose meter is medically essential to test blood glucose levels, and
the person for whom the non-conventional glucose meter has been prescribed is unable to use a conventional glucose meter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The period of time referred to in section 3 (3) (b) of this Schedule with respect to replacement of a non-conventional glucose meter is 5 years from the date on which the minister provided the glucose meter being replaced.
In this section, period means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of a person under 19 years of age, including a child in a home of a relative, a 2 year period beginning on January 1, 2017 and on each subsequent January 1 in an odd numbered year, and
in respect of a person not referred to in paragraph (a), a 2 year period beginning on January 1, 2003 and on each subsequent January 1 in an odd numbered year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The health supplements that may be paid under section 68 [dental supplements] of this regulation are basic dental services to a maximum of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: $2 000 each period, if provided to a person under 19 years of age, and
$1 000 each period, if provided to a person not referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Dentures may be provided as a basic dental service only to a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: who has never worn dentures, or
whose dentures are more than 5 years old.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The limits under subsection (1.1) may be exceeded by an amount necessary to provide dentures, taking into account the amount remaining to the person under those limits at the time the dentures are to be provided, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person requires a full upper denture, a full lower denture or both because of extractions made in the previous 6 months to relieve pain,

a person, other than a person who is a main continued person under section 66.3 (1) of this regulation as a result of having been part of a family unit identified in section 66.3 (3) (a) or a dependent continued person under section 66.3 (2) of that person, requires a partial denture to replace at least 3 contiguous missing teeth on the same arch, at least one of which was extracted in the previous 6 months to relieve pain, or
a person who has been a recipient of income assistance or disability assistance for at least 2 years or a dependant of that person requires replacement dentures.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) (b) does not apply with respect to a person described in subsection (3) (a) who has previously had a partial denture.
The dental supplements that may be provided to a person described in subsection (3) (b), or to a person described in subsection (3) (c) who requires a partial denture, are limited to services under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fee numbers 52101 to 52402 in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Dentist referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition "basic dental service" in section 1 of this Schedule, or
fee numbers 41610, 41612, 41620 and 41622 in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Denturist referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition "basic dental service" in section 1 of this Schedule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The dental supplements that may be provided to a person described in subsection (3) (c) who requires the replacement of a full upper, a full lower denture or both are limited to services under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fee numbers 51101 and 51102 in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Dentist referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition "basic dental service" in section 1 of this Schedule, or
fee numbers 31310, 31320 or 31330 in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Denturist referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition "basic dental service" in section 1 of this Schedule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A reline or a rebase of dentures may be provided as a basic dental service only to a person who has not had a reline or rebase of dentures for at least 2 years.
In this section, crown and bridgework means a dental service

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that is provided by a dentist,
that is set out in the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Crown and Bridgework, that is effective April 1, 2010 and is published on the website of the ministry of the minister,
that is provided at the rate set out for the service in that Schedule, and
for which a recipient has received the pre-authorization of the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health supplement may be paid under section 68.1 of this regulation for crown and bridgework but only if the minister is of the opinion that the recipient has a dental condition that cannot be corrected through the provision of basic dental services because

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the dental condition precludes the provision of the restorative services set out under the Restorative Services section of the Schedule of Fee Allowances — Dentist, and
one of the following circumstances exists:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the dental condition precludes the use of a removable prosthetic;
the recipient has a physical impairment that makes it impossible for the recipient to place a removable prosthetic;
the recipient has an allergic reaction or other intolerance to the composition or materials used in a removable prosthetic;
the recipient has a mental condition that makes it impossible for the recipient to assume responsibility for a removable prosthetic.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must also be satisfied that a health supplement for crown and bridgework will be adequate to correct the dental condition.
A health supplement for crown and bridgework may not be provided in respect of the same tooth more than once in any period of 60 calendar months.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The health supplements that may be provided under section 69 [denture supplements] of this regulation are denture services.
The health supplements that may be paid for under section 70 [emergency dental and denture supplements] of this regulation are emergency dental services.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dental and optical services — healthy kids program

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, period means a 2 year period beginning on January 1, 2017, and on each subsequent January 1 in an odd numbered year.

Subject to the following limits, the minister may pay under section 72 [dental and optical supplements — healthy kids] of this regulation for the following health care services for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age and who, when the service was provided, was eligible for supplemental services under section 10 (1) (c), (e) or (f) of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, or had been determined to be eligible for those services under section 11 of that regulation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: basic dental services, to a maximum total of $2 000 for each period for all basic dental services provided to the child during the period;
basic eyewear and repairs;
pre-authorized eyewear and repairs;
emergency dental services.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may pay under section 72.1 [hearing instrument supplement — healthy kids program] of this regulation for the following health care services for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age and who, when the service was provided, was eligible for supplemental services under section 10 (1) (c), (e) or (f) of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, or had been determined to be eligible for those services under section 11 of that regulation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a hearing instrument in accordance with sections 3 (1) (b) and 3.11 of this Schedule;
replacement of a hearing instrument in accordance with section 3 (3) and (6) of this Schedule;
repair of a hearing instrument in accordance with section 3 (4) to (6) of this Schedule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount of a diet supplement that may be provided under section 73 [diet supplement] of this regulation is as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: $15 for each calendar month for a person who requires a restricted sodium diet;
$60 for each calendar month for a person who has diabetes;
$50 for each calendar month for a person who requires kidney dialysis;
$65 for each calendar month for a person who requires a high protein diet;
$65 for each calendar month for a person who requires a gluten-free diet;
$65 for each calendar month for a person who has dysphagia;
$80 for each calendar month for a person who has cystic fibrosis;
$65 for each calendar month for which a person requires a ketogenic diet;
$65 for each calendar month for which a person requires a low phenylalanine diet.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A diet supplement under subsection (1) (d) may be provided only if the diet is confirmed by a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian as being necessary for one of the following medical conditions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cancer that requires nutritional support during

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: radiation therapy,
chemotherapy,
surgical therapy, or
ongoing medical treatment;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: chronic inflammatory bowel disease;
Crohn's disease;
ulcerative colitis;
HIV positive diagnosis;
AIDS;
chronic bacterial infection;
tuberculosis;
hyperthyroidism;
osteoporosis;
hepatitis B;
hepatitis C.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is eligible for a supplement under subsection (1) (d) or (f) is also eligible for a $50 payment towards the purchase of a blender.
If a person has more than one of the medical conditions set out in subsection (1), the person may receive only the amount of the highest diet supplement for which the person is eligible.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The amount of a natal supplement that may be provided under section 75 [natal supplement] of this regulation is as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: $80 for each calendar month for a period set out in section 75 (2), or
$160 for each calendar month for a period set out in section 75 (2) if the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is pregnant with more than one child, as confirmed in writing by a medical practitioner, a nurse practitioner or a midwife, or
gives birth to more than one child.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide infant formula under section 74.1 of this regulation if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner, midwife or dietitian confirms in writing that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the dependent child for whom a specialized infant formula is to be provided has a medical condition and the specialized infant formula is necessary to treat the medical condition,
the dependent child for whom the infant formula is to be provided is at risk of contracting a disease that is transmissible through the breast milk of the dependent child's parent, or
the nutritional needs of the dependent child for whom the infant formula is to be provided cannot be met through the breast milk of the dependent child's parent,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a child described by paragraph (a) (ii) or (iii), the child is 12 months of age or younger, and
the minister is satisfied that the infant formula is medically required to treat the medical condition, respond to the risk or meet the nutritional need referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, profound hearing loss means a hearing loss of 91 decibels or greater across all frequencies tested in an audiological assessment.

The amount of a hearing supplement that may be provided under section 77.02 or 77.03 of this regulation is $100 per calendar month to or for each person in a family unit to whom subsection (3) of this section applies.
The hearing supplement under subsection (2) may be provided by the minister only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister is satisfied that the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has permanent profound hearing loss in both ears, and
cannot benefit significantly, in respect of speech comprehension, from a hearing instrument, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an audiologist or hearing instrument practitioner, within the previous 12 months, has

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: performed an assessment that confirms the permanent profound hearing loss in both ears, and
provided an opinion that the person cannot benefit significantly, in respect of speech comprehension, from a hearing instrument.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The hearing supplement under subsection (2) may not be provided if a person received a hearing instrument under section 3.11 or 7.1 of this Schedule, or from another source, in the previous 36 months.

Despite subsection (4), the hearing supplement under subsection (2) may be provided to or for a person who received a hearing instrument in the previous 36 months if the person did not meet the requirements set out in subsection (3) on the date the person received the hearing instrument but subsequently meets those requirements.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No entitlement to a specific amount of hardship assistance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a family unit that is eligible for hardship assistance under Part 4 of this regulation an amount not exceeding the amounts authorized by this Schedule.
Subject to subsection (1), the actual amount of hardship assistance to be provided under this Schedule is in the discretion of the minister based on the financial need of the applicant's family unit.
Nothing in this Schedule or in Part 4 of this regulation entitles a family unit to a specific amount of hardship assistance.
In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: backdated Canada child benefit payment, in relation to a child benefits cheque, means the portion of the cheque, if any, attributable to the Canada child benefit for one or more calendar months preceding the calendar month in which the cheque is issued;

backdated family bonus payment, in relation to a child benefits cheque, means the portion of the cheque, if any, attributable to the family bonus for one or more calendar months preceding the calendar month in which the cheque is issued;

supplement means a supplement referred to in section 61 [supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled family bonus] or 61.1 [supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled Canada child benefit] of this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The maximum amount that the minister may provide to a family unit that is eligible for hardship assistance under Part 4 of this regulation is the difference between

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the sum of

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the support allowance under Table 1 that applies to the applicant's family unit,
the shelter allowance as calculated under section 4, and
any adjustment applicable under subsection (2), or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: calculated in accordance with section 5, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the sum of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the net income of the applicant's family unit, and
the value of the assets of the family unit that are immediately available to meet basic needs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the family unit includes one or more dependent children, the support allowance for the family unit for a calendar month may be increased by an amount equal to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total BC child adjustment amount for all dependent children in the family unit, minus
the sum of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the family bonus, if any, paid to the family unit for the preceding month,

the Canada child benefit, if any, paid to the family unit for the preceding month in respect of dependent children in the family unit, up to a maximum of the BC child adjustment amount in respect of those dependent children, and

the total amount of the supplements, if any, provided to or for the family unit under section 61 [supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled family bonus] or 61.1 [supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled Canada child benefit] of this regulation for the current calendar month.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the amount calculated under subsection (2) is less than zero, it is deemed to be zero for the purposes of this section.

In calculating the adjustment under subsection (2), an amount that, under the Income Tax Act (British Columbia) or the Income Tax Act (Canada), is deducted or set off from the family bonus or the Canada child benefit must be treated as if it were paid to a person in the family unit.
The support allowance under Table 1 for a calendar month may not be increased under subsection (2) if a person in the family unit refuses to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: apply for the family bonus or the Canada child benefit for the preceding calendar month, or
accept the family bonus or the Canada child benefit for the preceding calendar month

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in respect of a dependent child in the family unit who is, or may be, a qualified dependant within the meaning of the Income Tax Act (Canada).
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 270/2019, App. 1, s. 25 (b).]
In subsection (1), net income means the amount of unearned income, plus the amount of earned income minus deductions for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: income tax,
employment insurance,
medical insurance,
Canada Pension Plan,
superannuation,
company pension plan, and
union dues.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person in the applicant's or recipient's family unit receives a backdated family bonus payment or a backdated Canada child benefit payment and all or part of the payment is attributable to one or more calendar months for which the family unit was also provided with a supplement, the lesser of the following amounts must be treated as unearned income:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the portion of the backdated family bonus payment or the backdated Canada child benefit payment, as applicable, that is attributable to those calendar months for which the family unit was provided with a supplement;

the sum of the supplements that are attributable to those calendar months for which the family unit received the backdated family bonus payment or the backdated Canada child benefit payment, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (7), an amount that, under the Income Tax Act (British Columbia) or the Income Tax Act (Canada), is deducted or set off from a family bonus or a Canada child benefit must be treated as paid to a person in the applicant's family unit.
Subsection (7) does not apply to an amount included in that portion of a child benefits cheque attributable to family bonus or Canada child benefit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to replace a lost or stolen cheque for which an amount was advanced under section 60 [advance for lost or stolen family bonus cheque] or 60.1 [advance for lost or stolen child benefits cheque — Canada child benefit] of this regulation, or

to replace a cheque for which no amount was advanced under section 60 [advance for lost or stolen family bonus cheque] or 60.1 [advance for lost or stolen child benefits cheque — Canada child benefit] of this regulation if the replacement is received in the calendar month following the calendar month for which the lost or stolen cheque was issued.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 48/2010, Sch. 1, s. 1 (s).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsections (1) to (9) but subject to subsection (11), hardship assistance may not be provided in respect of a dependent child if support for that child is provided under section 8 (2) or 93 (1) (g) (ii) of the Child, Family and Community Service Act.
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application is made by a parenting dependent child under section 5 (4) [application by parent who is dependent youth] of this regulation as it applies in relation to hardship assistance,
the family unit is found eligible for hardship assistance, and
support is provided for the parenting dependent child or that individual's dependent child, or for both, under section 8 (2) or 93 (1) (g) (ii) of the Child, Family and Community Service Act,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the restriction in subsection (10) does not apply, but the amount of hardship assistance that may otherwise be provided to the family unit is to be reduced by the amount of that support.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Any amount provided under this Schedule for support is intended to be used by the recipient to meet the food, clothing and transportation needs of the family unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant is eligible for a shelter allowance for the applicant's family unit in an amount equal to the greater of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minimum set out in Table 2 for the family unit, and
the lesser of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the family unit's actual shelter costs, as calculated in accordance with sections 4 (5) [monthly shelter allowance] and 5 [how actual shelter costs are calculated] of Schedule A, and
the maximum set out in Table 2 for the family unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: applicants in a family unit complete and submit an application for income assistance (part 2) form or an alternate application for income assistance form, and
for the calendar month that includes the income assistance application date, a portion of the shelter costs for that family unit has been paid,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the applicants may receive a shelter allowance under this Schedule of not more than the portion of the rent for that calendar month that remains unpaid on that date.
As an exception to subsection (2), if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: applicants in a family unit complete and submit an application for income assistance (part 2) form for the purpose of applying for hardship assistance under section 47.2, and

for the calendar month that includes the date on which the minister determines that the family unit is eligible for hardship assistance under that section, a portion of the shelter costs for that family unit has been paid,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the applicants may receive a shelter allowance under this Schedule of not more than the portion of the rent for that calendar month that remains unpaid on that date.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the minimum and maximum shelter allowance for a family unit of more than 10 persons is to be calculated as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minimum is to be calculated by adding $25 for each additional person;
the maximum is to be calculated by adding $50 for each additional person.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A supplement that is paid under section 65 of the regulation may include the following amounts:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amount for a funeral provider's fee for services;
an amount for the costs of intraprovincial transportation, if that transportation is for a distance greater than 32 kilometres;
in respect of a burial, an amount for the costs set out in section 4 of this Schedule;
in respect of a cremation, an amount for the costs set out in section 5 of this Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The services provided in respect of a funeral provider's fee for services must include:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: intraprovincial transportation, if that transportation is for a distance of 32 kilometres or less;
completion and filing of the registration of death;
obtaining a burial or cremation permit;
co-ordination with a crematorium and cemetery;
all professional and staff services;
preparation of a deceased person's body for burial or cremation, including basic sanitary care and casketing;
use of the funeral provider's facilities and equipment, including a preparation room, refrigeration and parking and service areas;
other items or services incidental to or provided as part of any of the services described in paragraphs (a) to (g), as agreed by the funeral services provider and the responsible person.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Mileage for intraprovincial transportation for a distance greater than 32 kilometres must not exceed the rate set out in Column 2 of the Table below opposite the distance set out in Column 1.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A supplement payable in respect of a burial may include an amount for the following costs:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cost of a burial plot in British Columbia;
grave opening and closing fees;
if a grave liner, hermetically sealed rigid container, plastic body pouch or outer grave box or liner is required by the cemetery, the cost of the liner, container, pouch or box;
the cost of a casket, in an amount representing the sum of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the actual factory invoice price of a HP #2 cloth-covered casket or an equivalent or, in the case of over-sized remains, a casket for over-sized remains;
a merchandising mark-up of up to 20%;
the cost of freight to the funeral home.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A lower cost casket may be used at the request of a responsible person.

The minister may pay for the remains of a deceased person to be interred at a location within British Columbia other than the location at which the remains were prepared for burial in an amount not to exceed the amount that would be payable for the costs described in subsection (1) (a) to (c) and intraprovincial transportation costs.
A supplement payable in respect of a cremation may include an amount for the following costs:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cremation fees;
the cost of a cremation plot in British Columbia;
grave opening and closing fees;
if a concrete grave liner is required by the cemetery, the cost of the grave liner;
the cost of an urn in an amount not to exceed $200.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may pay for the remains of a deceased person to be interred at a location within British Columbia other than the location at which the remains were cremated in an amount not to exceed the amount that would be payable for the costs described in subsection (1) (b) to (d).
